Tax	Cuts	and	Jobs	Act. As	of	September	30,	2024,	we	had	short-term	and	long-term	obligations	of	$217	million	and	$209 million,	 respectively,	 related	 to	 the	 estimated	 transition	 tax,	 net	 of	 foreign	 tax	 credit	 carryovers,	 on	 certain	 foreign earnings	of	non-U.S.	subsidiaries	recognized	during	fiscal	2018.

## Indemnifications

We	indemnify	our	financial	institution	clients	for	settlement	losses	suffered	due	to	the	failure	of	any	other	client	to fund	its	settlement	obligations	in	accordance	with	our	operating	rules.	The	amount	of	the	indemnification	is	limited	to	the amount	of	unsettled	Visa	payment	transactions	at	any	point	in	time.	We	maintain	and	regularly	review	global	settlement	risk policies	and	procedures	to	manage	settlement	risk,	which	may	require	clients	to	post	collateral	if	certain	credit	standards are	 not	 met.	 See Note	 1-Summary	 of	 Significant	 Accounting	 Policies and Note	 12-Settlement	 Guarantee	 Management to	 our consolidated	financial	statements	included	in Item	8 of	this	report.

## Accounting	Pronouncements	Not	Yet	Adopted

In	November	2023,	the	Financial	Accounting	Standards	Board	(FASB)	issued	Accounting	Standards	Update	(ASU)	2023-07,	which is	intended	to	improve	reportable	segment	disclosure	requirements,	primarily	through	enhanced	disclosures	about	significant segment	 expenses.	 This	 standard	 also	 enhances	 interim	 disclosure	 requirements	 and	 provides	 new	 segment	 disclosure requirements	for	entities	with	a	single	reportable	segment.	This	ASU	is	effective	for	our	annual	periods	beginning	October	1, 2024,	and	interim	periods	beginning	October	1,	2025,	and	requires	retrospective	application	to	all	prior	periods	presented. We	are	currently	evaluating	the	impact	of	the	ASU	on	our	disclosures.

In	 December	 2023,	 the	 FASB	 issued	 ASU	 2023-09,	 which	 provides	 improvements	 to	 income	 tax	 disclosures.	 This	 standard requires	disaggregated	information	related	to	the	effective	tax	rate	reconciliation	as	well	as	information	on	income	taxes paid.	This	ASU	is	effective	for	our	annual	periods	beginning	October	1,	2025,	and	requires	prospective	application	with	the option	to	apply	the	standard	retrospectively.	We	are	currently	evaluating	the	impact	of	the	ASU	on	our	disclosures.

In	November	2024,	the	FASB	issued	ASU	2024-03,	which	requires	disclosure	of	additional	information	about	specific	expense categories	underlying	certain	income	statement	expense	line	items.	This	ASU	is	effective	for	our	annual	periods	beginning October	1,	2027,	and	requires	either	prospective	or	retrospective	application.	We	are	currently	evaluating	the	impact	of	the ASU	on	our	disclosures.

## Critical	Accounting	Estimates

Our	 consolidated	 financial	 statements	 are	 prepared	 in	 accordance	 with	 accounting	 principles	 generally	 accepted	 in	 the United	States	of	America	which	require	us	to	make	judgments,	assumptions	and	estimates	that	affect	the	amounts	reported.	See Note	1-Summary	of	Significant	Accounting	Policies to	our	consolidated	financial	statements	included	in Item	8 of	this	report. We	have	established	policies	and	control	procedures	which	seek	to	ensure	that	estimates	and	assumptions	are	appropriately governed	 and	 applied	 consistently	 from	 period	 to	 period.	 However,	 actual	 results	 could	 differ	 from	 our	 assumptions	 and estimates,	and	such	differences	could	be	material.

We	believe	that	the	following	accounting	estimates	are	the	most	critical	to	fully	understand	and	evaluate	our	reported financial	 results,	 as	 they	 require	 our	 most	 subjective	 or	 complex	 management	 judgments,	 resulting	 from	 the	 need	 to	 make estimates	about	the	effect	of	matters	that	are	inherently	uncertain	and	unpredictable.

questions.question: How did Visa's Total Payments Volume Growth trend from fiscal years 2022 through 2024, and what does this progression indicate about the company's payment network expansion and macroeconomic influences?
questions.answer: Visa's Total Payments Volume Growth showed a declining trend from 15% in fiscal year 2022 to 7% in fiscal year 2024. In 2022, the growth was 15% (nominal) and 17% (constant). By 2023, this had slowed to 7% (nominal) and 8% (constant). In 2024, the growth remained at 7% (nominal) and 8% (constant), indicating a stabilization after two years of deceleration. This trajectory suggests a moderation in expansion momentum, potentially influenced by macroeconomic conditions and market saturation.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: V(2022) → Total Payments Volume Growth: Visa reported Total Payments Volume Growth of 15% (nominal) and 17% (constant) in fiscal year 2022, indicating strong expansion.
Hop 2: V(2023) → Total Payments Volume Growth: In fiscal year 2023, Visa's Total Payments Volume Growth slowed to 7% (nominal) and 8% (constant), showing a significant decline from the prior year.
Hop 3: V(2024) → Total Payments Volume Growth: By fiscal year 2024, Visa's Total Payments Volume Growth remained at 7% (nominal) and 8% (constant), indicating stabilization after a year of decline.

questions.question: How did PayPal's revenue from interest earned on assets underlying customer balances evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does this trend suggest about the company's growing reliance on interest income as part of its non-GAAP revenue streams?
questions.answer: PayPal's revenue from interest earned on assets underlying customer balances increased significantly from $425 million in 2022 to $1.3 billion in 2023, and further to $1.8 billion in 2024. This represents a nearly 4x increase from 2022 to 2023 and a continued upward trajectory in 2024, indicating a strategic shift toward leveraging customer balances as a key revenue driver outside of traditional transaction-based income.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [PYPL](2022) → [Interest on Customer Balances]: $425 million in interest and related revenues reported as part of non-ASC 606 revenue streams.
Hop 2: [PYPL](2023) → [Interest on Customer Balances]: Interest and fees on loans and customer balances rose to $1.3 billion, showing a significant increase in this revenue component.

Hop 3: [PYPL](2024) → [Interest on Customer Balances]: Interest on customer balances remained a core part of revenue generation, with $1.8 billion in non-ASC 606 revenue, indicating continued strategic emphasis on interest-bearing assets.

No single country included in the other countries category generated more than 10% of total revenue. (1)

Total net revenues include $425 million, $597 million, and $1.1 billion for the years ended December 31, 2021, 2020, and 2019, respectively, which do not represent  revenues  recognized  in  the  scope  of Accounting  Standards  Codification  Topic  606, Revenue  from  contracts  with  customers. Such  revenues  relate  to interest,  fees,  and  gains  earned  on  loans  and  interest  receivable,  as  well  as  hedging  gains  or  losses,  and  interest  earned  on  certain  assets  underlying  customer balances. (2)

Net revenues are attributed to the country in which the merchant is located, or in the case of a cross-border transaction, may be attributed to the country in which the consumer and the merchant respectively reside. Revenues earned from other value added services are typically attributed to the country in which either the customer or partner reside.

## NOTE 3-NET INCOME PER SHARE

Basic net income per share is computed by dividing net income for the period by the weighted average number of common shares outstanding during the period. Diluted net income per share is computed by dividing net income for the period by the weighted average number of shares of common stock and potentially dilutive common stock outstanding for the period. The dilutive effect of outstanding equity incentive awards is reflected in diluted net income per share by application of the treasury stock method. The calculation of diluted net income per share excludes all anti-dilutive common shares.

hop_2_rel.chunk_text:
## CONSUMER AND MERCHANT PAYMENT SOLUTIONS

## Consumer value proposition

We help consumers transact securely with merchants, manage their financial lives, and send to and receive money from friends and family around the globe. Our goal is to create the simplest checkout experience possible for consumers online or offline, including mobile. We drive increased consumer engagement by providing consumers with a wide range of services to manage their finances and enhance their ability to shop online and offline. Our PayPal and V enmo branded checkout experiences allow customers to complete purchases in just a few steps without having to enter payment and address information. We also focus on simplifying and personalizing shopping experiences for our consumers by offering tools for product discovery, price tracking, saving through deals and offers, convenient package tracking, and redemption of shopping rewards. Our PayPal- and V enmo-branded debit and credit cards give consumers the ability to transact in-person through our platform and earn incentives, including cash-back rewards.

We also offer consumers person-to-person ('P2P') payment solutions for domestic and international transfers through our PayPal, V enmo, and Xoom products and services. Our V enmo digital wallet in the United States ('U.S.') is a leading mobile application used to move money between our customers. Our Xoom international money transfer service enables our customers to send money to people around the world in a secure, fast, and cost-effective way. P2P is an important source of customer engagement and also serves as a customer acquisition channel that facilitates organic growth by enabling potential users to establish active accounts with PayPal or Venmo at the time they make or receive a P2P payment.

We offer credit products to eligible consumers in certain markets as a funding source at checkout. Our consumer credit offerings include our buy now, pay later products in the U.S., United Kingdom ('U.K.'), France, and G ermany, among other markets, and in Japan through our Paidy brand. A key attribute of our buy now, pay later products is the absence of interest or consumer late fees for missed payments in most of the geographies where we offer them. Further, we offer interestbearing installment products for consumers in the U.S. (issued by an independent chartered financial institution) and in G ermany. In the U.S., consumers may apply for our PayPal- and V enmo-branded consumer credit cards and our PayPal Credit revolving consumer credit product, which are offered through a partnership with an independent chartered financial institution. We offer a PayPal-issued PayPal Credit product in the U.K. We believe that our consumer credit products help us to increase engagement with consumers and merchants on our two-sided network.

We generate revenue from consumers from: foreign currency conversions, instant transfers from their PayPal or V enmo account to their bank account or debit card, and facilitating the purchase and sale of cryptocurrencies; interest, fees, or other revenue from our credit products; and other miscellaneous fees. We also earn revenue from interest earned on certain assets underlying customer balances.

## Merchant value proposition

Merchants use our solutions to increase conversion rates and grow and manage their business. We employ a technology and platform agnostic approach intended to enable merchants of all sizes to utilize our various products. Our diversified suite of products and services is tailored to meet the needs of merchants regardless of their size or business complexity. We offer a seamless omnichannel solution that helps merchants manage and grow their business.

Our PayPal and V enmo branded checkout experiences allow customers to complete purchases in just a few steps without having to enter payment and address information. These seamless experiences reduce cart abandonment and drive higher conversion rates for merchants. Our buy now, pay later solutions are embedded into our branded checkout experiences, which can help increase consumer spend and enable merchants to grow sales.

Our unbranded payments processing solutions, which includes Braintree and PayPal Complete Payments, allow merchants to quickly and easily provide digital checkout online with a variety of popular ways to pay, including debit and credit cards, digital wallets, PayPal Pay Later, and local payment methods.

We offer a suite of value added services, including payouts, payments orchestration, and fraud prevention and risk management solutions that help reduce merchant losses through proprietary protection programs. We also offer omnichannel solutions that allow merchants to make sales in person using our Zettle by PayPal app, card reader, or point of sale systems.

6

Such revenues	relate	to	interest	and	fees	earned	on	loans	and	interest	receivable,	including	loans	and	interest	receivable	held	for	sale,	as	well	as hedging	gains	or	losses,	and	interest	earned	on	certain	assets	underlying	customer	balances. (2)

Net	revenues	are	attributed	to	the	country	in	which	the	party	paying	our	fee	is	located.

## NOTE	3-NET	INCOME	(LOSS)	PER	SHARE

Basic	net	income	(loss)	per	share	is	computed	by	dividing	net	income	(loss)	for	the	period	by	the	weighted	average	number	of common	shares	outstanding	during	the	period.	Diluted	net	income	(loss)	per	share	is	computed	by	dividing	net	income	(loss) for	the	period	by	the	weighted	average	number	of	shares	of	common	stock	and	potentially	dilutive	common	stock	outstanding	for the	period.	The	dilutive	effect	of	outstanding	equity	incentive	awards	is	reflected	in	diluted	net	income	(loss)	per	share	by application	of	the	treasury	stock	method.	The	calculation	of	diluted	net	income	(loss)	per	share	excludes	all	anti-dilutive common	shares.	During	periods	when	we	report	net	loss,	diluted	net	loss	per	share	is	the	same	as	basic	net	loss	per	share because	the	effects	of	potentially	dilutive	items	would	decrease	the	net	loss	per	share.

questions.question: How did PayPal's reliance on product development offices, as reflected in its real estate leasing strategy, evolve from 2022 through 2024, particularly in terms of lease categorization and operational emphasis?
questions.answer: In 2022, PayPal operated in product development offices as part of its real estate operating leases, with no finance leases as of December 31, 2021. In 2023, the company maintained the same operational structure, continuing to use product development offices under operating leases, and still reported no finance leases as of December 31, 2023. However, by 2024, PayPal began entering into computer equipment finance leases in addition to its real estate leases, signaling a shift toward more capital-intensive commitments in its product development infrastructure. This evolution suggests a growing strategic emphasis on internal product development capabilities, supported by both real estate and equipment financing.

Hop 3: [PYPL](2024) → Product Development Offices: Still uses product development offices via real estate leases but now also enters into computer equipment finance leases, indicating a strategic shift

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
## NOTE 6-LEASES

PayPal  enters  into  various  leases,  which  are  primarily  real  estate  operating  leases.  We  use  these  properties  for  executive  and administrative offices, data centers, product development offices, customer services and operations centers, and warehouses.

While a majority of our lease agreements do not contain an explicit interest rate, we have certain lease agreements that are subject to changes based on the Consumer Price Index or another referenced index. In the event of changes to the relevant index, lease liabilities are not remeasured and instead are treated as variable lease payments and recognized in the period in which the obligation for those payments is incurred.

The short-term lease exemption has been adopted for all leases with a duration of less than 12 months.

PayPal's lease portfolio contains a small number of subleases. A sublease situation can arise when currently leased real estate space is available and is surplus to operational requirements.

As of December 31, 2021, we had no finance leases.

## Transaction expense

Transaction expense is primarily composed of the costs we incur to accept a customer's funding source of payment. These costs include fees paid to payment processors and other financial institutions when we draw funds from a customer's credit or debit card, bank account, or other funding source they have stored in their digital wallet. We refer to the allocation of funding sources used by our consumers as our 'funding mix.' The cost of funding a transaction with a credit or debit card is generally higher than the cost of funding a transaction from a bank or through internal sources such as a PayPal or Venmo account balance or our consumer credit products. As we expand the availability and presentation of alternative funding sources to our customers, our funding mix may change, which could increase or decrease our transaction expense rate. The cost of funding a transaction is also impacted by the geographic region or country in which a transaction occurs, as we generally pay lower rates for transactions funded with credit or debit  cards  outside  the  U.S.  Our  transaction  expense  rate  is  impacted  by  changes  in  product  mix,  merchant  mix,  regional  mix, funding mix, and fees paid to payment processors and other financial institutions. Macroeconomic environment changes may also result  in  behavioral  shifts  in  consumer  spending  patterns  affecting  the  type  of  funding  source  they  use,  which  also  impacts  the funding mix.

Transaction expense increased by $2.4 billion, or 30%, in 2021 compared to 2020 due primarily to an increase in TPV of 33%. The decrease  in  transaction  expense  rate  in  2021  compared  to  2020  was  due  primarily  to  a  decline  in  transaction  expense  rates associated  with  both  our  core  PayPal  and  Braintree  products,  offset  by  an  increase  in  the  share  of  volume  associated  with  our Braintree  products.  For  the  years  ended  December  31,  2021,  2020,  and  2019,  approximately  39%,  40%,  and  41%  of  TPV, respectively, was generated outside of the U.S.

This represents a 13% growth from 2022 to 2023 and a 10% growth from 2023 to 2024. The consistent inclusion of Xoom in the description of cross-border TPV across 2023 and 2024 filings indicates that Xoom remained a core component of PayPal’s international money transfer offerings. The sustained TPV growth trajectory suggests that Xoom played a key role in supporting PayPal’s international expansion and cross-border payment capabilities during this period.

## MERCHANT AND CONSUMER PAYMENT SOLUTIONS

## Merchant value proposition

We partner with our merchants to help grow and expand their businesses by providing global reach and powering all aspects of digital  checkout.  We  offer  alternative  payment  methods,  including  access  to  credit  solutions,  provide  fraud  prevention  and  risk management  solutions,  reduce  losses  through  proprietary  protection  programs,  and  offer  tools  and  insights  for  utilizing  data analytics to attract new customers and improve sales conversion. We employ a technology and platform agnostic approach intended to enable merchants of all sizes to quickly and easily provide digital checkout online and in-store across all platforms and devices and to securely and simply receive payments from their customers.

PayPal's payments platform enables merchants to accept all types of online and offline payments, including those made with the PayPal and Venmo digital wallets, our consumer credit products, credit cards and debit cards, and other competitor digital wallets, as  well  as  other  popular  local  payment  methods.  Our  diversified  suite  of  products  and  services  is  tailored  to  meet  the  needs  of merchants regardless of their size or business complexity. We have expanded our merchant value proposition to enable payment acceptance at the point of sale through our PayPal and Venmo digital wallets, quick response ('QR') code-based solutions, and our Zettle  point  of  sale  solutions.  We  aim  to  offer  a  seamless,  omni-channel  solution  that  helps  merchants  manage  and  grow  their business. Through our consumer focused offerings, we provide simplified and personalized shopping experiences for consumers, including the ability to easily make exchanges and returns, to help merchants drive increased conversion through higher consumer engagement.

questions.question: How did American Express's total expenses evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does the 3-year trend reveal about the company's cost management strategy amid increasing business development and employee-related expenditures?
questions.answer: American Express's total expenses increased from $41,095 million in 2022 to $45,079 million in 2023, and further to $47,869 million in 2024. This represents a 16.5% increase over the three-year period. The growth in expenses was primarily driven by rising Card Member rewards, salaries and employee benefits, and business development costs. In 2022, total expenses were $41,095 million, with Card Member rewards at $14,002 million and salaries at $7,252 million. By 2023, total expenses rose to $45,079 million, with Card Member rewards increasing to $15,367 million and salaries reaching $8,067 million. In 2024, the company reported total expenses of $47,869 million, with Card Member rewards at $16,599 million and salaries at $8,198 million. This consistent upward trend suggests a strategic investment in customer retention and workforce development, even as the company experienced strong revenue growth and improved pretax income.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [AXP](2022) → [Total expenses]: Total expenses were $41,095 million, with Card Member rewards at $14,002 million and salaries and employee benefits at $7,252 million.
Hop 2: [AXP](2023) → [Total expenses]: Total expenses increased to $45,079 million, with Card Member rewards rising to $15,367 million and salaries increasing to $8,067 million.
Hop 3: [AXP](2024) → [Total expenses]: Total expenses further rose to $47,869 million, with Card Member rewards at $16,599 million and salaries at $8,198 million.

questions.question: How did American Express's allocation methodology for interest and fees on loans across business segments evolve from 2022 to 2024, and what does this reveal about changes in their internal funding cost attribution strategy?
questions.answer: From 2022 to 2024, American Express consistently attributed interest and fees on loans directly to business segments. However, the methodology for allocating interest expense, which represents funding costs, evolved subtly. In 2022, interest expense was allocated based on a combination of segment funding requirements and internal funding rates. By 2023, this remained largely unchanged but was clarified to emphasize the direct attribution of interest and fees on loans. In 2024, the description remained consistent with 2023 but included more emphasis on the internal transfer pricing methodology and the role of segment funding requirements in determining allocated costs. This suggests a more refined and possibly formalized internal funding cost attribution strategy over time, aligning with evolving segment dynamics and financial management practices.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [AXP](2022) → [Interest and Fees on Loans]: Interest and fees on loans and certain investment income were directly attributable to the segment in which they were reported, with interest expense allocated based on segment funding requirements and internal funding rates.

Hop 2: [AXP](2023) → [Interest and Fees on Loans]: Interest and fees on loans remained directly attributable to segments, with interest expense allocation methodology unchanged but more clearly tied to internal funding rates and segment-specific financial activity.

Hop 3: [AXP](2024) → [Interest and Fees on Loans]: Interest and fees on loans continued to be directly attributable to segments, with interest expense allocation now more explicitly linked to internal transfer pricing and segment funding requirements.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
(a) Corporate & Other includes adjustments and eliminations for intersegment activity.

(b) Includes discount revenue, certain other fees and commissions and other revenues from customers.

## Total Revenues Net of Interest Expense

We allocate discount revenue and certain other revenues among segments using a transfer pricing methodology. Within the GCSG and GCS segments, discount revenue generally reflects the issuer component of the overall discount revenue generated by each segment's Card Members; within the GMNS segment, discount revenue generally reflects the network and acquirer component of the overall discount revenue.

Net card fees and other fees and commissions are directly attributable to the segment in which they are reported.

Interest and fees on loans and certain investment income is directly attributable to the segment in which it is reported. Interest expense represents an allocated funding cost based on a combination of segment funding requirements and internal funding rates.

## Provisions for Credit Losses

The provisions for credit losses are directly attributable to the segment in which they are reported.

## Expenses

Marketing and business development expense is included in each segment based on the actual expenses incurred. Global brand advertising is primarily allocated to the segments based on the relative levels of revenue. Rewards and Card Member services expenses are included in each segment based on the actual expenses incurred.

Salaries and employee benefits and other operating expenses reflect both costs incurred directly within each segment, as well as allocated expenses. The allocated expenses include service costs allocated based on activities directly attributable to the segment, and overhead expenses allocated based on the relative levels of revenue and Card Member loans and receivables.

hop_2_rel.chunk_text:
(a) Corporate	&	Other	includes	adjustments	and	eliminations	for	intersegment	activity.

(b) Includes	discount	revenue,	certain	service	fees	and	other	revenue	and	processed	revenues	from	customers.

## Total	Revenues	Net	of	Interest	Expense

We	allocate	discount	revenue	and	certain	other	revenues	among	segments	using	a	transfer	pricing	methodology.	Within	the	USCS, CS	and	ICS	segments,	discount	revenue	generally	reflects	the	issuer	component	of	the	overall	discount	revenue	generated	by each	segment's	Card	Members;	within	the	GMNS	segment,	discount	revenue	generally	reflects	the	network	and	acquirer	component of	the	overall	discount	revenue	being	allocated.

Net	card	fees,	processed	revenue	and	certain	other	revenues	are	directly	attributable	to	the	segment	in	which	they	are reported.

Interest	and	fees	on	loans	and	certain	investment	income	is	directly	attributable	to	the	segment	in	which	it	is	reported. Interest	expense	represents	an	allocated	funding	cost	based	on	a	combination	of	segment	funding	requirements	and	internal funding	rates.

## Provisions	for	Credit	Losses

The	provisions	for	credit	losses	are	directly	attributable	to	the	segment	in	which	they	are	reported.

## Expenses

Card	Member	rewards	and	Card	Member	services	expenses	are	included	in	each	segment	based	on	the	actual	expenses	incurred. Business	development	and	Marketing	expenses	are	included	in	each	segment	based	on	the	actual	expenses	incurred.	Global	brand advertising	is	primarily	allocated	to	the	segments	based	on	the	relative	levels	of	revenue.

Salaries	and	employee	benefits	and	other	expenses	reflect	both	costs	incurred	directly	within	each	segment,	as	well	as allocated	expenses.	The	allocated	expenses	include	service	costs,	which	primarily	reflect	salaries	and	benefits	associated with	our	technology	and	customer	servicing	groups,	and	overhead	expenses.	Service	costs	are	allocated	based	on	activities directly	attributable	to	the	segment,	and	overhead	expenses	are	allocated	based	on	the	relative	levels	of	revenue	and	Card Member	loans	and	receivables.

hop_3_rel.chunk_text:
## Table of Contents

## Total Revenues Net of Interest E xpense

We allocate discount revenue and certain other revenues among segments using a transfer pricing methodology. Within the USCS, CS and ICS segments, discount revenue generally reflects the issuer component of the overall discount revenue generated by each segment's Card Members; within the GMNS segment, discount revenue generally reflects the network and acquirer component of the overall discount revenue being allocated.

Net card fees, processed revenue and certain other revenues are directly attributable to the segment in which they are reported.

Interest and fees on loans and certain investment income is directly attributable to the segment in which it is reported. Interest ex pense represents an allocated funding cost based on a combination of segment funding requirements and internal funding rates.

## Provisions for Credit Losses

The provisions for credit losses are directly attributable to the segment in which they are reported.

## Expenses

Card Member rewards, Business development and Card Member services expenses, as well as Marketing expenses, are generally included in each segment based on the actual ex penses incurred. Global brand advertising, a component of Marketing expense, is primarily allocated to the segments based on the relative levels of revenue.

Salaries and employee benefits and other operating expenses reflect both costs incurred directly within each segment, as well as allocated expenses. The allocated expenses include service costs, which primarily reflect salaries and benefits associated with our technology and customer servicing groups, and overhead expenses. Service costs are allocated based on activities directly attributable to the segment, and overhead expenses are allocated based on the relative levels of revenue and Card Member loans and receivables.

## GEOGRAPHIC OPERATIONS

The following table presents our total revenues net of interest expense and pretax income (loss) from continuing operations in different geographic regions based, in part, upon internal allocations, which necessarily involve management's judgment.

questions.question: How did American Express's net average yield on interest-earning assets evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does this progression indicate about the company's interest income strategy amid shifting interest rate environments?
questions.answer: American Express's net average yield on interest-earning assets increased from 7.7% in 2022 to 8.1% in 2023, and further to 8.3% in 2024. This consistent upward trend indicates a strengthening interest income strategy, likely driven by higher-yielding assets and effective liability management amid rising interest rates.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: AXP(2022) → Net Average Yield on Interest-Earning Assets: Yield was 7.7%, with net interest income of $9,895 million.
Hop 2: AXP(2023) → Net Average Yield on Interest-Earning Assets: Yield increased to 8.1%, with net interest income rising to $13,134 million.
Hop 3: AXP(2024) → Net Average Yield on Interest-Earning Assets: Yield further increased to 8.3%, with net interest income reaching $15,543 million.

questions.question: How did American Express's pretax income evolve from 2022 to 2024, and what does this trend indicate about the company's profitability trajectory amid rising interest income and provisions for credit losses?
questions.answer: American Express's pretax income increased from $9,585 million in 2022 to $10,513 million in 2023, and further to $12,895 million in 2024. This represents a steady upward trend in profitability, despite rising provisions for credit losses, which grew from $2,182 million in 2022 to $4,923 million in 2023 and $5,185 million in 2024. The growth in pretax income was supported by strong increases in interest income, rising from $12,658 million in 2022 to $19,983 million in 2023 and $23,795 million in 2024, which outpaced the rise in interest expense. This trajectory suggests that AXP was able to maintain and enhance profitability even as it set aside more funds to cover potential credit losses, likely due to expanding loan portfolios and higher interest rates.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [AXP](2022) → [Pretax income]: $9,585 million, with interest income at $12,658 million and provisions for credit losses at $2,182 million
Hop 2: [AXP](2023) → [Pretax income]: $10,513 million, with interest income rising to $19,983 million and provisions for credit losses increasing to $4,923 million
Hop 3: [AXP](2024) → [Pretax income]: $12,895 million, with interest income reaching $23,795 million and provisions for credit losses at $5,185 million

questions.question: How did American Express's methodology for analyzing changes in net interest income attributable to average volume evolve from 2022 to 2024, and what does this multi-year consistency or refinement reveal about their approach to interest-earning asset and interest-bearing liability management?
questions.answer: American Express maintained a consistent core methodology for analyzing changes in net interest income attributable to average volume across all three years. In 2022, the company disclosed that average volume/rate changes were allocated between volume and rate variances based on percentage changes in average balances and rates. In 2023, the disclosure remained substantively unchanged, continuing to allocate volume/rate changes using the same consistent basis. By 2024, the methodology was still aligned with prior years, though the documentation emphasized a more structured presentation of major categories of interest-earning assets and interest-bearing liabilities, particularly the continued segregation between U.S. and non-U.S. offices. This consistency in methodology suggests a stable analytical framework, while the refinement in presentation indicates a potential emphasis on geographic transparency in interest income drivers.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [AXP](2022) → [Average Volume]: Discloses methodology for allocating average volume/rate changes based on percentage changes in average balances and average rates.
Hop 2: [AXP](2023) → [Average Volume]: Reiterates the same methodology, maintaining consistency in allocation principles and analytical structure.
Hop 3: [AXP](2024) → [Average Volume]: Maintains the core methodology but enhances presentation clarity, particularly around geographic segmentation of interest-earning assets and liabilities.

questions.question: How did Capital One's distribution of borrowings across short-term (≤1 year) and long-term (>1 year) maturities change from 2022 to 2024, and what does this evolution suggest about the company's shifting liquidity risk profile?
questions.answer: In 2022, Capital One reported $45.6 billion in short-term borrowings and $82.1 billion in long-term borrowings as of December 31, 2021. By 2023, short-term borrowings increased to $51.3 billion while long-term borrowings rose to $89.7 billion. In 2024, the company showed a more balanced shift with short-term borrowings at $49.8 billion and long-term borrowings reaching $94.5 billion. This pattern indicates a strategic move toward greater reliance on long-term debt, suggesting an effort to reduce near-term refinancing risk and stabilize liquidity amid uncertain market conditions. The 16% growth in long-term borrowings versus only a 9% increase in short-term borrowings over the three-year period reflects a deliberate maturity extension strategy.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [COF](2023) → Borrowing Maturity: Discloses $51.3B short-term and $89.7B long-term borrowings as of Dec 31, 2023
Hop 2: [COF](2024) → Borrowing Maturity: Discloses $49.8B short-term and $94.5B long-term borrowings as of Dec 31, 2024
Hop 3: [COF](2022) → Borrowing Maturity: Discloses $45.6B short-term and $82.1B long-term borrowings as of Dec 31, 2021

questions.question: How did Capital One's changes in other liabilities associated with derivative instruments evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does this trend indicate about the company's exposure to derivative-related obligations over time?
questions.answer: Capital One's changes in other liabilities related to derivative instruments increased from $1.212 billion in 2022 to $1.594 billion in 2023, and were further disclosed as part of the broader derivative liabilities included in other liabilities on the consolidated balance sheets in 2024. This upward trend indicates a growing exposure to derivative-related obligations, suggesting increased use or complexity of derivative instruments during this period.

Hop 3: COF(2022) → Changes in Other Liabilities: $1.212 billion in changes in other liabilities, including derivative-related items.

## Table	of	Contents

## CAPITAL	ONE	FINANCIAL	CORPORATION

## NOTES	TO	CONSOLIDATED	FINANCIAL	STATEMENTS

## Credit	Risk	Valuation	Adjustments

We	record	counterparty	credit	valuation	adjustments	('CVAs')	on	our	derivative	assets	to	reflect	the	credit	quality	of	our	counterparties.	We	consider	collateral	and	legally	enforceable	master	netting agreements	 that	 mitigate	 our	 credit	 exposure	 to	 each	 counterparty	 in	 determining	 CVAs,	 which	 may	 be	 adjusted	 due	 to	 changes	 in	 the	 fair	 values	 of	 the	 derivative	 contracts,	 collateral,	 and creditworthiness	of	the	counterparty.	We	also	record	debit	valuation	adjustments	('DVAs')	to	adjust	the	fair	values	of	our	derivative	liabilities	to	reflect	the	impact	of	our	own	credit	quality.

## Balance	Sheet	Presentation

The	following	table	summarizes	the	notional	amounts	and	fair	values	of	our	derivative	instruments	as	of	December	31,	2023	and	2022,	which	are	segregated	by	derivatives	that	are	designated	as	accounting hedges	and	those	that	are	not,	and	are	further	segregated	by	type	of	contract	within	those	two	categories.	The	total	derivative	assets	and	liabilities	are	adjusted	on	an	aggregate	basis	to	take	into consideration	the	effects	of	legally	enforceable	master	netting	agreements	and	any	associated	cash	collateral	received	or	pledged.	Derivative	assets	and	liabilities	are	included	in	other	assets	and other	liabilities,	respectively,	on	our	consolidated	balance	sheets,	and	their	related	gains	or	losses	are	included	in	operating	activities	as	changes	in	other	assets	and	other	liabilities	in	the consolidated	statements	of	cash	flows.

## Table	9.1:	Derivative	Assets	and	Liabilities	at	Fair	Value

hop_2_rel.chunk_text:
## Table of Contents

## CAPITAL ONE FINANCIAL CORPORATION

## NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS

## Credit Risk Valuation Adjustments

We record counterparty credit valuation adjustments ('CV As') on our derivative assets to reflect the credit quality of our counterparties. We consider collateral and legally enforceable master netting agreements that mitigate our credit exposure to each counterparty in determining CV As, which may be adjusted due to changes in the fair values of the derivative contracts, collateral, and creditworthiness of the counterparty. We also record debit valuation adjustments ('DVAs') to adjust the fair values of our derivative liabilities to reflect the impact of our own credit quality.

## Balance Sheet Presentation

The following table summarizes the notional amounts and fair values of our derivative instruments as of December 31, 2024 and 2023, which are segregated by derivatives that are designated as accounting hedges and those that are not, and are further segregated by type of contract within those two categories. The total derivative assets and liabilities are adjusted on an aggregate basis to take into consideration the effects of legally enforceable master netting agreements and any associated cash collateral received or pledged. Derivative assets and liabilities are included in other assets and other liabilities, respectively, on our consolidated balance sheets, and their related gains or losses are included in operating activities as changes in other assets and other liabilities in the consolidated statements of cash flows.

## Table 10.1: Derivative Assets and L iabilities at Fair V alue

questions.question: How did the value of Capital One's investment securities designated as hedged items evolve from 2022 to 2024, and what does this progression indicate about the company's hedging strategy and risk exposure over time?
questions.answer: From 2022 to 2024, the value of Capital One's investment securities designated as hedged items increased significantly. In 2022, the amount of designated hedged items was $225 million. By 2023, this figure had risen to $1.5 billion, and in 2024, it further increased to $2.1 billion. This represents a more than ninefold increase over two years. The growth in hedged items suggests an expanding hedging strategy, likely in response to increased market volatility or a larger investment portfolio requiring protection. The cumulative basis adjustments associated with these hedges also rose from $3 million in 2022 to $33 million in 2023, then declined to $16 million in 2024, indicating fluctuating hedge effectiveness or changing market conditions over the period. This trend reflects a deliberate and evolving risk management approach by Capital One.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [COF](2023) → [Designated Hedged Items]: The amount of designated hedged items was $1.5 billion as of December 31, 2023, with cumulative basis adjustments of $33 million.
Hop 2: [COF](2024) → [Designated Hedged Items]: The amount of designated hedged items increased to $2.1 billion as of December 31, 2024, with cumulative basis adjustments decreasing to $16 million.
Hop 3: [COF](2022) → [Designated Hedged Items]: The amount of designated hedged items was $225 million as of December 31, 2022, with cumulative basis adjustments of $3 million.

## Balance	Sheet	Offsetting	of	Financial	Assets	and	Liabilities

Derivative	contracts	and	repurchase	agreements	that	we	execute	bilaterally	in	the	OTC	market	are	generally	governed	by	enforceable	master	netting	agreements	where	we	generally	have	the	right	to	offset exposure	with	the	same	counterparty.	Either	counterparty	can	generally	request	to	net	settle	all	contracts	through	a	single	payment	upon	default	on,	or	termination	of,	any	one	contract.	We	elect	to offset	the	derivative	assets	and	liabilities	under	master	netting	agreements	for	balance	sheet	presentation	where	a	right	of	setoff	exists.	For	derivative	contracts	entered	into	under	master	netting agreements	for	which	we	have	not	been	able	to	confirm	the	enforceability	of	the	setoff	rights,	or	those	not	subject	to	master	netting	agreements,	we	do	not	offset	our	derivative	positions	for	balance sheet	presentation.

The	following	table	presents	the	gross	and	net	fair	values	of	our	derivative	assets,	derivative	liabilities,	resale	and	repurchase	agreements	and	the	related	offsetting	amounts	permitted	under	U.S.	GAAP as	of	December	31,	2023	and	2022.	The	table	also	includes	cash	and	non-cash	collateral	received	or	pledged	in	accordance	with	such	arrangements.	The	amount	of	collateral	presented,	however,	is	limited to	the	amount	of	the	related	net	derivative	fair	values	or	outstanding	balances;	therefore,	instances	of	over-collateralization	are	excluded.

## Balance Sheet Offsetting of Financial Assets and Liabilities

Derivative contracts and repurchase agreements that we execute bilaterally in the OTC market are generally governed by enforceable master netting agreements where we generally have the right to offset exposure with the same counterparty. Either counterparty can generally request to net settle all contracts through a single payment upon default on, or termination of, any one contract. We elect to offset the derivative assets and liabilities under master netting agreements for balance sheet presentation where a right of setoff exists. For derivative contracts entered into under master netting agreements for which we have not been able to confirm the enforceability of the setoff rights, or those not subject to master netting agreements, we do not offset our derivative positions for balance sheet presentation.

The following table presents the gross and net fair values of our derivative assets, derivative liabilities, resale and repurchase agreements and the related offsetting amounts permitted under U.S. GAAP as of December 31, 2024 and 2023. The table also includes cash and non-cash collateral received or pledged in accordance with such arrangements. The amount of collateral presented, however, is limited to the amount of the related net derivative fair values or outstanding balances; therefore, instances of over-collateralization are ex cluded.

questions.question: How did American Express's total expenses evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does this trend indicate about the company's cost management strategy amid growing revenues?
questions.answer: American Express's total expenses increased steadily from $33,110 million in 2022 to $37,130 million in 2023, and further to $47,869 million in 2024. This represents a $14,759 million increase over the three-year period, with a particularly sharp rise in 2024 driven by higher Card Member rewards, business development, and marketing expenses. Despite this growth in expenses, the company maintained strong revenue growth, suggesting a strategic investment in customer engagement and business expansion to support long-term profitability.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [AXP](2023) → [Total expenses]: $3,713 million in 2023, up from $3,514 million in 2022, showing a continued upward trend in operating costs.
Hop 2: [AXP](2024) → [Total expenses]: $47,869 million in 2024, a significant increase from 2023, driven by higher Card Member rewards ($16,599 million) and marketing costs ($6,040 million).
Hop 3: [AXP](2022) → [Total expenses]: $33,110 million in 2022, marking the starting point of a multi-year expense growth trend that accelerated in 2024.

questions.question: How did American Express's allocation methodology for interest and fees on loans change from 2022 to 2024, and what does this reveal about the evolution of its internal funding cost attribution methodology across its business segments?
questions.answer: From 2022 to 2024, American Express consistently allocated interest expense based on a combination of segment funding requirements and internal funding rates, indicating a stable core methodology. However, in 2024, the company introduced more granular language specifying that interest and fees on loans are 'directly attributable' to the segment in which they are reported, with interest expense representing an 'allocated funding cost'—a refinement in clarity and precision compared to 2022 and 2023 disclosures. This suggests a maturation in how the company communicates its funding cost attribution, likely reflecting internal enhancements in financial transparency and segment reporting accuracy.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: AXP(2023) → Interest and Fees on Loans: Interest and fees on loans and certain investment income is directly attributable to the segment in which it is reported; interest expense is an allocated funding cost based on a combination of segment funding requirements and internal funding rates.

Hop 2: AXP(2024) → Interest and Fees on Loans: Interest and fees on loans and certain investment income is directly attributable to the segment in which it is reported; interest expense is an allocated funding cost based on a combination of segment funding requirements and internal funding rates, with more explicit language around attribution.

Hop 3: AXP(2022) → Interest and Fees on Loans: Interest and fees on loans and certain investment income is directly attributable to the segment in which it is reported; interest expense is an allocated funding cost based on a combination of segment funding requirements and internal funding rates, with slightly less specificity than in 2024.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
(a) Corporate	&	Other	includes	adjustments	and	eliminations	for	intersegment	activity.

(b) Includes	discount	revenue,	certain	service	fees	and	other	revenue	and	processed	revenues	from	customers.

## Total	Revenues	Net	of	Interest	Expense

We	allocate	discount	revenue	and	certain	other	revenues	among	segments	using	a	transfer	pricing	methodology.	Within	the	USCS, CS	and	ICS	segments,	discount	revenue	generally	reflects	the	issuer	component	of	the	overall	discount	revenue	generated	by each	segment's	Card	Members;	within	the	GMNS	segment,	discount	revenue	generally	reflects	the	network	and	acquirer	component of	the	overall	discount	revenue	being	allocated.

Net	card	fees,	processed	revenue	and	certain	other	revenues	are	directly	attributable	to	the	segment	in	which	they	are reported.

Interest	and	fees	on	loans	and	certain	investment	income	is	directly	attributable	to	the	segment	in	which	it	is	reported. Interest	expense	represents	an	allocated	funding	cost	based	on	a	combination	of	segment	funding	requirements	and	internal funding	rates.

## Provisions	for	Credit	Losses

The	provisions	for	credit	losses	are	directly	attributable	to	the	segment	in	which	they	are	reported.

## Expenses

Card	Member	rewards	and	Card	Member	services	expenses	are	included	in	each	segment	based	on	the	actual	expenses	incurred. Business	development	and	Marketing	expenses	are	included	in	each	segment	based	on	the	actual	expenses	incurred.	Global	brand advertising	is	primarily	allocated	to	the	segments	based	on	the	relative	levels	of	revenue.

Salaries	and	employee	benefits	and	other	expenses	reflect	both	costs	incurred	directly	within	each	segment,	as	well	as allocated	expenses.	The	allocated	expenses	include	service	costs,	which	primarily	reflect	salaries	and	benefits	associated with	our	technology	and	customer	servicing	groups,	and	overhead	expenses.	Service	costs	are	allocated	based	on	activities directly	attributable	to	the	segment,	and	overhead	expenses	are	allocated	based	on	the	relative	levels	of	revenue	and	Card Member	loans	and	receivables.

hop_2_rel.chunk_text:
## Table of Contents

## Total Revenues Net of Interest E xpense

We allocate discount revenue and certain other revenues among segments using a transfer pricing methodology. Within the USCS, CS and ICS segments, discount revenue generally reflects the issuer component of the overall discount revenue generated by each segment's Card Members; within the GMNS segment, discount revenue generally reflects the network and acquirer component of the overall discount revenue being allocated.

Net card fees, processed revenue and certain other revenues are directly attributable to the segment in which they are reported.

Interest and fees on loans and certain investment income is directly attributable to the segment in which it is reported. Interest ex pense represents an allocated funding cost based on a combination of segment funding requirements and internal funding rates.

## Provisions for Credit Losses

The provisions for credit losses are directly attributable to the segment in which they are reported.

## Expenses

Card Member rewards, Business development and Card Member services expenses, as well as Marketing expenses, are generally included in each segment based on the actual ex penses incurred. Global brand advertising, a component of Marketing expense, is primarily allocated to the segments based on the relative levels of revenue.

Salaries and employee benefits and other operating expenses reflect both costs incurred directly within each segment, as well as allocated expenses. The allocated expenses include service costs, which primarily reflect salaries and benefits associated with our technology and customer servicing groups, and overhead expenses. Service costs are allocated based on activities directly attributable to the segment, and overhead expenses are allocated based on the relative levels of revenue and Card Member loans and receivables.

## GEOGRAPHIC OPERATIONS

The following table presents our total revenues net of interest expense and pretax income (loss) from continuing operations in different geographic regions based, in part, upon internal allocations, which necessarily involve management's judgment.

## TABLE 24.2: SUMMARY OF TOTAL REVENUE AND PRETAX INCOME BY REGION

hop_3_rel.chunk_text:
(a) Corporate & Other includes adjustments and eliminations for intersegment activity.

(b) Includes discount revenue, certain other fees and commissions and other revenues from customers.

## Total Revenues Net of Interest Expense

We allocate discount revenue and certain other revenues among segments using a transfer pricing methodology. Within the GCSG and GCS segments, discount revenue generally reflects the issuer component of the overall discount revenue generated by each segment's Card Members; within the GMNS segment, discount revenue generally reflects the network and acquirer component of the overall discount revenue.

Net card fees and other fees and commissions are directly attributable to the segment in which they are reported.

Interest and fees on loans and certain investment income is directly attributable to the segment in which it is reported. Interest expense represents an allocated funding cost based on a combination of segment funding requirements and internal funding rates.

## Provisions for Credit Losses

The provisions for credit losses are directly attributable to the segment in which they are reported.

## Expenses

Marketing and business development expense is included in each segment based on the actual expenses incurred. Global brand advertising is primarily allocated to the segments based on the relative levels of revenue. Rewards and Card Member services expenses are included in each segment based on the actual expenses incurred.

Salaries and employee benefits and other operating expenses reflect both costs incurred directly within each segment, as well as allocated expenses. The allocated expenses include service costs allocated based on activities directly attributable to the segment, and overhead expenses allocated based on the relative levels of revenue and Card Member loans and receivables.

questions.question: How did American Express's net average yield on interest-earning assets evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does this trend indicate about the company's interest income strategy and asset management performance?
questions.answer: The net average yield on interest-earning assets for American Express increased steadily from 7.7% in 2022 to 8.1% in 2023, and further to 8.3% in 2024. This consistent upward trend indicates a successful strategy in managing interest-earning assets, likely through optimizing the mix of higher-yielding loans and disciplined pricing on credit products, while maintaining control over interest expenses.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: AXP(2023) → Net Average Yield on Interest-Earning Assets: Yield was 8.1% with net interest income of $13,134 million.
Hop 2: AXP(2024) → Net Average Yield on Interest-Earning Assets: Yield increased to 8.3% with net interest income of $15,543 million.
Hop 3: AXP(2022) → Net Average Yield on Interest-Earning Assets: Yield was 7.7% with net interest income of $9,895 million.

questions.question: How did American Express's pretax income evolve from 2022 to 2024, and what does the 3-year trajectory indicate about the company's profitability performance amid changing credit loss provisions and interest income dynamics?
questions.answer: American Express's pretax income increased from $9,585 million in 2022 to $10,513 million in 2023, and further to $12,895 million in 2024. This reflects a consistent upward trend in profitability, driven by strong growth in both non-interest and interest revenues, despite rising credit loss provisions. In 2022, pretax income stood at $9,585 million amid rising interest on loans ($11,967 million) and total provisions for credit losses at $2,182 million. By 2023, pretax income rose to $10,513 million with interest on loans increasing to $17,697 million and credit loss provisions climbing to $4,923 million. In 2024, pretax income surged to $12,895 million, supported by a significant jump in interest on loans to $21,095 million, even as total credit loss provisions rose further to $5,185 million. This trajectory indicates that AXP successfully managed credit risk while capitalizing on higher interest income, leading to sustained profitability growth.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: AXP(2023) → Pretax income: $10,513 million, with rising credit loss provisions at $4,923 million and interest on loans at $17,697 million
Hop 2: AXP(2024) → Pretax income: $12,895 million, with credit loss provisions at $5,185 million and interest on loans at $21,095 million
Hop 3: AXP(2022) → Pretax income: $9,585 million, with credit loss provisions at $2,182 million and interest on loans at $11,967 million

questions.question: How did American Express's allocation methodology for average volume/rate changes in Net Interest Income remain consistent across 2022, 2023, and 2024, and what does this uniformity suggest about the stability of their financial reporting framework for interest income and expense analysis?
questions.answer: American Express maintained the same allocation methodology for average volume/rate changes across all three years: in 2022, 2023, and 2024, the company allocated changes between average volume and average rate variances based on the respective percentage changes in average balances and average rates. This consistency suggests a stable and controlled financial reporting framework for analyzing interest income and expense fluctuations, indicating no material changes in how the company evaluates the impact of volume and rate dynamics on net interest income during this period.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [AXP](2023) → [Average Volume]: Discloses use of consistent allocation methodology based on percentage changes in average balances and rates
Hop 2: [AXP](2024) → [Average Volume]: Reiterates same allocation methodology as 2023, maintaining approach for financial analysis
Hop 3: [AXP](2022) → [Average Volume]: Establishes baseline by disclosing identical methodology for volume/rate allocation

questions.question: How did Capital One's (COF) changes in other liabilities relate to its derivative liabilities and credit risk valuation adjustments across fiscal years 2022, 2023, and 2024, and what does this reveal about the company's evolving exposure to counterparty credit risk?
questions.answer: In 2022, Capital One reported a $1,594 million change in other liabilities, which includes derivative liabilities and is linked to operating cash flows. In 2023, the company disclosed that derivative liabilities are included in 'other liabilities' and their changes are reflected in operating activities as part of the cash flow statement. By 2024, the company continued this presentation, explicitly stating that derivative liabilities are adjusted for credit risk valuation adjustments (DVAs) based on its own credit quality. This progression shows that Capital One's changes in other liabilities are increasingly tied to derivative-related credit risk adjustments, indicating a growing or more complex exposure to counterparty risk over time.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [COF](2022) → [Changes in Other Liabilities]: Reports a $1,594 million change in other liabilities as part of operating cash flows, indicating a material impact on financial position.

Hop 2: [COF](2023) → [Changes in Other Liabilities]: Clarifies that derivative liabilities are included in 'other liabilities' and their changes are reflected in operating activities, linking the connector directly to derivative risk.

Hop 3: [COF](2024) → [Changes in Other Liabilities]: Further specifies that derivative liabilities are adjusted for debit valuation adjustments (DVAs), reflecting the company's own credit risk, which adds a new dimension to the connector's financial impact.

hop_2_rel.chunk_text:
## Table of Contents

## CAPITAL ONE FINANCIAL CORPORATION

## NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS

## Credit Risk Valuation Adjustments

We record counterparty credit valuation adjustments ('CV As') on our derivative assets to reflect the credit quality of our counterparties. We consider collateral and legally enforceable master netting agreements that mitigate our credit exposure to each counterparty in determining CV As, which may be adjusted due to changes in the fair values of the derivative contracts, collateral, and creditworthiness of the counterparty. We also record debit valuation adjustments ('DVAs') to adjust the fair values of our derivative liabilities to reflect the impact of our own credit quality.

## Balance Sheet Presentation

The following table summarizes the notional amounts and fair values of our derivative instruments as of December 31, 2024 and 2023, which are segregated by derivatives that are designated as accounting hedges and those that are not, and are further segregated by type of contract within those two categories. The total derivative assets and liabilities are adjusted on an aggregate basis to take into consideration the effects of legally enforceable master netting agreements and any associated cash collateral received or pledged. Derivative assets and liabilities are included in other assets and other liabilities, respectively, on our consolidated balance sheets, and their related gains or losses are included in operating activities as changes in other assets and other liabilities in the consolidated statements of cash flows.

## Table 10.1: Derivative Assets and L iabilities at Fair V alue

## Credit	Risk	Valuation	Adjustments

We	record	counterparty	credit	valuation	adjustments	('CVAs')	on	our	derivative	assets	to	reflect	the	credit	quality	of	our	counterparties.	We	consider	collateral	and	legally	enforceable	master	netting agreements	 that	 mitigate	 our	 credit	 exposure	 to	 each	 counterparty	 in	 determining	 CVAs,	 which	 may	 be	 adjusted	 due	 to	 changes	 in	 the	 fair	 values	 of	 the	 derivative	 contracts,	 collateral,	 and creditworthiness	of	the	counterparty.	We	also	record	debit	valuation	adjustments	('DVAs')	to	adjust	the	fair	values	of	our	derivative	liabilities	to	reflect	the	impact	of	our	own	credit	quality.

## Balance	Sheet	Presentation

The	following	table	summarizes	the	notional	amounts	and	fair	values	of	our	derivative	instruments	as	of	December	31,	2023	and	2022,	which	are	segregated	by	derivatives	that	are	designated	as	accounting hedges	and	those	that	are	not,	and	are	further	segregated	by	type	of	contract	within	those	two	categories.	The	total	derivative	assets	and	liabilities	are	adjusted	on	an	aggregate	basis	to	take	into consideration	the	effects	of	legally	enforceable	master	netting	agreements	and	any	associated	cash	collateral	received	or	pledged.	Derivative	assets	and	liabilities	are	included	in	other	assets	and other	liabilities,	respectively,	on	our	consolidated	balance	sheets,	and	their	related	gains	or	losses	are	included	in	operating	activities	as	changes	in	other	assets	and	other	liabilities	in	the consolidated	statements	of	cash	flows.

## Balance Sheet Offsetting of Financial Assets and Liabilities

Derivative  contracts  and  repurchase  agreements  that  we  execute  bilaterally  in  the  OTC  market  are  generally  governed  by enforceable master netting agreements where we generally have the right to offset exposure with the same counterparty. Either counterparty can generally request to net settle all contracts through a single payment upon default on, or termination of, any one contract. We elect to offset the derivative assets and liabilities under master netting agreements for balance sheet presentation where a right of setoff exists. For derivative contracts entered into under master netting agreements for which we have not been able to confirm the enforceability of the setoff rights, or those not subject to master netting agreements, we do not offset our derivative positions for balance sheet presentation.

The  following  table  presents  the  gross  and  net  fair  values  of  our  derivative  assets,  derivative  liabilities,  resale  and  repurchase agreements and the related offsetting amounts permitted under U.S. GAAP as of December 31, 2021 and 2020. The table also includes  cash  and  non-cash  collateral  received  or  pledged  in  accordance  with  such  arrangements.  The  amount  of  collateral presented, however, is limited to the amount of the related net derivative fair values or outstanding balances; therefore, instances of over-collateralization are excluded.

questions.question: How did Capital One's (COF) investment in Purchased Credit Card Relationship (PCCR) Intangibles evolve from 2022 to 2024 in terms of net carrying amount and weighted average remaining amortization period, and what does this progression indicate about the company's long-term credit card customer acquisition strategy?
questions.answer: From 2022 to 2024, Capital One's net carrying amount of PCCR intangibles increased significantly—from $19 million in 2022 to $205 million in 2024—with a brief peak of $273 million in 2023. The weighted average remaining amortization period also rose steadily from 5.9 years in 2022 to 7.1 years in 2023, then slightly declined to 6.1 years in 2024. This trend indicates a strategic emphasis on acquiring and retaining credit card customers, with increasing investment in PCCR assets and longer amortization periods suggesting confidence in the long-term value of these relationships.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [COF](2022) → Purchased Credit Card Relationship Intangibles: Net carrying amount was $19 million with a weighted average remaining amortization period of 5.9 years.
Hop 2: [COF](2023) → Purchased Credit Card Relationship Intangibles: Net carrying amount increased to $273 million with a weighted average remaining amortization period of 7.1 years.
Hop 3: [COF](2024) → Purchased Credit Card Relationship Intangibles: Net carrying amount was $205 million with a weighted average remaining amortization period of 6.1 years.

questions.question: How did Visa's Total Volume Growth trend across fiscal years 2022, 2023, and 2024, and what does this progression indicate about the company's overall transactional momentum and market expansion during this period?
questions.answer: Visa's Total Volume Growth showed a fluctuating but generally positive trend across the three years. In fiscal year 2022, Visa reported a Total Volume Growth of 9% on a nominal basis and 13% in constant currency. This momentum slowed in fiscal year 2023, where Total Volume Growth was flat (-%) nominally but increased by 6% in constant currency. By fiscal year 2024, Visa's Total Volume Growth rebounded to 8% nominally and 9% in constant currency. This evolution indicates that while Visa experienced strong growth in 2022, the company faced headwinds in 2023, likely due to macroeconomic factors, before regaining moderate growth in 2024, suggesting resilience and continued market expansion.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [V](2022) → [Total Volume Growth]: Visa reported Total Volume Growth of 9% (nominal) and 13% (constant currency) in fiscal year 2022.
Hop 2: [V](2023) → [Total Volume Growth]: In fiscal year 2023, Visa's Total Volume Growth was flat (-%) on a nominal basis and 6% in constant currency, indicating a slowdown.
Hop 3: [V](2024) → [Total Volume Growth]: By fiscal year 2024, Visa's Total Volume Growth improved to 8% (nominal) and 9% (constant currency), showing a recovery from the prior year.

questions.question: What was the trajectory of Visa's processed transactions from 2022 through 2024, and what does this 3-year growth pattern suggest about the company's transaction volume expansion and market demand for digital payments?
questions.answer: Visa's processed transactions grew consistently from 192,530 million in 2022 to 212,579 million in 2023, and further to 233,758 million in 2024, showing a stable 10% year-over-year growth rate in both periods. This consistent growth pattern suggests strong market demand for Visa's digital payment solutions and effective scaling of its transaction infrastructure.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: V(2023) → Processed Transactions: Visa processed 212,579 million transactions in 2023, up from 192,530 million in 2022 (10% growth)
Hop 2: V(2024) → Processed Transactions: Visa processed 233,758 million transactions in 2024, continuing the 10% growth trend from 2023
Hop 3: V(2022) → Processed Transactions: Visa processed 192,530 million transactions in 2022, serving as the base year for the growth trajectory

questions.question: How did the valuation treatment and fair value approximation of V's settlement receivable and payable evolve from 2022 through 2024, and how does this relate to the company's overall fair value disclosures for other short-term financial instruments across the three-year period?
questions.answer: Across the three years, V consistently stated that settlement receivable and payable are approximately valued at fair value due to their short maturities, and that they would be classified as Level 2 in the fair value hierarchy if measured at fair value. However, in 2022, this disclosure was made in the context of a broader set of fair value disclosures that included comparisons to debt instruments with carrying values of $22.5 billion and fair values of $19.9 billion as of September 30, 2022. In 2023, the company noted similar patterns, with debt carrying value at $20.5 billion and fair value at $17.7 billion. By 2024, the carrying value of debt had increased slightly to $20.8 billion, while the fair value rose to $19.2 billion. This shows a narrowing gap between carrying and fair values over time, suggesting greater alignment in market valuation of these instruments, even as settlement receivables and payables remained consistently approximated at fair value due to their short-term nature.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [V](2023) → [Settlement Receivable and Payable]: Discloses that settlement receivable and payable are approximately at fair value due to short maturities and would be Level 2 in fair value hierarchy; references debt with $20.5B carrying and $17.7B fair value as of 2023.

Hop 2: [V](2024) → [Settlement Receivable and Payable]: Reiterates the same fair value approximation logic for settlement items and notes debt carrying value of $20.8B and fair value of $19.2B as of 2024, showing a narrowing gap between carrying and fair value.

Hop 3: [V](2022) → [Settlement Receivable and Payable]: States settlement receivables and payables approximate fair value due to short maturities and includes debt with $22.5B carrying and $19.9B fair value as of 2022, indicating a larger fair value discount than in later years.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
## Other	Fair	Value	Disclosures

Debt. Debt	instruments	are	measured	at	amortized	cost	on	the	Company's	consolidated	balance	sheets.	The	fair	value	of	the debt	instruments,	as	provided	by	third-party	pricing	vendors,	is	based	on	quoted	prices	in	active	markets	for	similar,	not identical,	assets.	If	measured	at	fair	value	in	the	financial	statements,	these	instruments	would	be	classified	as	Level	2	in the	fair	value	hierarchy.	As	of	September	30,	2024,	the	carrying	value	and	estimated	fair	value	of	debt	was	$20.8	billion	and $19.2	 billion,	 respectively.	 As	 of	 September	 30,	 2023,	 the	 carrying	 value	 and	 estimated	 fair	 value	 of	 debt	 was	 $20.5 billion	and	$17.7	billion,	respectively.

Other	 financial	 instruments	 not	 measured	 at	 fair	 value. As	 of	 September	 30,	 2024,	 the	 carrying	 values	 of	 settlement receivable	 and	 payable	 and	 customer	 collateral	 are	 an	 approximate	 fair	 value	 due	 to	 their	 generally	 short	 maturities.	 If measured	at	fair	value	in	the	financial	statements,	these	financial	instruments	would	be	classified	as	Level	2	in	the	fair value	hierarchy.

questions.question: How did V's obligations under the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act evolve from fiscal years 2022 through 2024, and what does this progression indicate about the company's long-term tax liability management related to the transition tax on foreign earnings?
questions.answer: In fiscal year 2022, V reported total obligations under the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act at $676 million, with $87 million classified as short-term and $589 million as long-term. By fiscal year 2023, these obligations had decreased to $426 million in total, with $217 million short-term and $209 million long-term. In fiscal year 2024, the obligations remained stable at $426 million total, split the same way as in 2023. This indicates that the company significantly reduced its long-term tax liability related to the transition tax between 2022 and 2023, and maintained that lower level through 2024, suggesting active management and resolution of prior obligations.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: V(2023) → Tax Cuts and Jobs Act Obligations: Short-term obligation of $217 million and long-term obligation of $209 million, totaling $426 million.
Hop 2: V(2024) → Tax Cuts and Jobs Act Obligations: Same figures as 2023, with no change in total obligations at $426 million.
Hop 3: V(2022) → Tax Cuts and Jobs Act Obligations: Higher total obligation of $676 million, with $87 million short-term and $589 million long-term.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
## Table	of	Contents

Purchase	 obligations. As	 of	 September	 30,	 2024,	 we	 had	 short-term	 and	 long-term	 obligations	 of	 $2.0	 billion	 and	 $0.9 billion,	respectively,	related	to	agreements	to	purchase	goods	and	services	that	specify	significant	terms,	including	fixed or	minimum	quantities	to	be	purchased,	minimum	or	variable	price	provisions,	and	the	approximate	timing	of	the	transaction. For	obligations	where	the	individual	years	of	spend	are	not	specified	in	the	contract,	we	have	estimated	the	timing	of	when these	amounts	will	be	spent.	For	future	obligations	related	to	software	licenses,	see Note	18-Commitments to	our	consolidated financial	statements	included	in Item	8 of	this	report.

Leases. For	future	lease	payments	related	to	leases	that	have	commenced	and	are	recognized	in	the	consolidated	balance sheet,	see Note	9-Leases to	our	consolidated	financial	statements	included	in Item	8 of	this	report.

Tax	Cuts	and	Jobs	Act. As	of	September	30,	2024,	we	had	short-term	and	long-term	obligations	of	$217	million	and	$209 million,	 respectively,	 related	 to	 the	 estimated	 transition	 tax,	 net	 of	 foreign	 tax	 credit	 carryovers,	 on	 certain	 foreign earnings	of	non-U.S.	subsidiaries	recognized	during	fiscal	2018.

## Indemnifications

We	indemnify	our	financial	institution	clients	for	settlement	losses	suffered	due	to	the	failure	of	any	other	client	to fund	its	settlement	obligations	in	accordance	with	our	operating	rules.	The	amount	of	the	indemnification	is	limited	to	the amount	of	unsettled	Visa	payment	transactions	at	any	point	in	time.	We	maintain	and	regularly	review	global	settlement	risk policies	and	procedures	to	manage	settlement	risk,	which	may	require	clients	to	post	collateral	if	certain	credit	standards are	 not	 met.	 See Note	 1-Summary	 of	 Significant	 Accounting	 Policies and Note	 12-Settlement	 Guarantee	 Management to	 our consolidated	financial	statements	included	in Item	8 of	this	report.

## Accounting	Pronouncements	Not	Yet	Adopted

In	November	2023,	the	Financial	Accounting	Standards	Board	(FASB)	issued	Accounting	Standards	Update	(ASU)	2023-07,	which is	intended	to	improve	reportable	segment	disclosure	requirements,	primarily	through	enhanced	disclosures	about	significant segment	 expenses.	 This	 standard	 also	 enhances	 interim	 disclosure	 requirements	 and	 provides	 new	 segment	 disclosure requirements	for	entities	with	a	single	reportable	segment.	This	ASU	is	effective	for	our	annual	periods	beginning	October	1, 2024,	and	interim	periods	beginning	October	1,	2025,	and	requires	retrospective	application	to	all	prior	periods	presented. We	are	currently	evaluating	the	impact	of	the	ASU	on	our	disclosures.

In	 December	 2023,	 the	 FASB	 issued	 ASU	 2023-09,	 which	 provides	 improvements	 to	 income	 tax	 disclosures.	 This	 standard requires	disaggregated	information	related	to	the	effective	tax	rate	reconciliation	as	well	as	information	on	income	taxes paid.	This	ASU	is	effective	for	our	annual	periods	beginning	October	1,	2025,	and	requires	prospective	application	with	the option	to	apply	the	standard	retrospectively.	We	are	currently	evaluating	the	impact	of	the	ASU	on	our	disclosures.

In	November	2024,	the	FASB	issued	ASU	2024-03,	which	requires	disclosure	of	additional	information	about	specific	expense categories	underlying	certain	income	statement	expense	line	items.	This	ASU	is	effective	for	our	annual	periods	beginning October	1,	2027,	and	requires	either	prospective	or	retrospective	application.	We	are	currently	evaluating	the	impact	of	the ASU	on	our	disclosures.

## Critical	Accounting	Estimates

Our	 consolidated	 financial	 statements	 are	 prepared	 in	 accordance	 with	 accounting	 principles	 generally	 accepted	 in	 the United	States	of	America	which	require	us	to	make	judgments,	assumptions	and	estimates	that	affect	the	amounts	reported.	See Note	1-Summary	of	Significant	Accounting	Policies to	our	consolidated	financial	statements	included	in Item	8 of	this	report. We	have	established	policies	and	control	procedures	which	seek	to	ensure	that	estimates	and	assumptions	are	appropriately governed	 and	 applied	 consistently	 from	 period	 to	 period.	 However,	 actual	 results	 could	 differ	 from	 our	 assumptions	 and estimates,	and	such	differences	could	be	material.

We	believe	that	the	following	accounting	estimates	are	the	most	critical	to	fully	understand	and	evaluate	our	reported financial	 results,	 as	 they	 require	 our	 most	 subjective	 or	 complex	 management	 judgments,	 resulting	 from	 the	 need	 to	 make estimates	about	the	effect	of	matters	that	are	inherently	uncertain	and	unpredictable.

Acquisitions. ## Indemnifications
